text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today I'm 
going to show you a dish that I used to love as a

kid and I still love it today but I have perfected 
it over the year so it's much better now than it

was when I was a kid I'm making what's called 
kai toon kai means eggs and Toon is I

guess a word you can use for steaming so it's 
steamed egg custard and it comes in individual

little cups it's going to be great I love having 
it for breakfast and it's super easy so let's get

started so the first thing I'm going to make is 
an herb paste it's going to be the main flavor of

the custard and it's a classic combination of 
white peppercorns garlic and cilantro roots I

need this pace to be very very fine otherwise 
it's you know the Custer is not going to be

super smooth so I will grind the white peppercorns 
first to make sure it's really really powderized

now that it is completely completely fine I'm 
going to add my garlic and also cilantro roots

of you don't have Santa routes on so stems would 
be okay and if you want you can just use a coffee

grinder for this without the coffee clean it 
out obviously so once I get it to sort of what

I think is as fine as I can I'm going to add some 
salt and sugar which is going to help sort of add

friction and help it grind a little bit better 
sugar to cut the salt you're not going to taste

sweetness in this but it will balance it out now 
it's really really fine I'm going to add some of

my stock so I've got some pork stock but you can 
use chicken stock or any homemade stock is better

that's unsalted is the important part I'm just 
going to rinse the mortar with some of the stock

so I don't have to scrape all this stuff off okay 
so I've got three eggs and what I'm doing is I'm

beating the eggs without creating air bubbles some 
kind of suring more than beating if I have a lot

of bubbles then my custard won't be smooth some 
soy sauce to flavor that so most of it is gone

I still have a bit of a glue penis but that's 
okay I'm going to add the rest of my stock and

adding this stock is going to make the custard 
really soft and silky so now that it's mostly

mixed I'm going to add my herb pace I'm going to 
strain this and I just noticed that I should have

straightened it before I add it all my herb paste 
because now I'm going to strain out some of the

your paste well that's okay it was very very 
fine so normally what you would do is strain

it and then at this and then at the herb paste 
but this is okay what I was really trying to get

out is all these egg white bits that that's not 
that's going to interfere with the smoothness of

the custard all right so let's talk filling and 
containers so first of all containers I'm using

these little ramekins so cute and I think it's a 
great individual size cup so this would be great

for one person to have with rice but if you want 
the whole thing to be like a meal in and of itself

maybe something a little bigger would work but 
whatever you want okay now filling normally for

sort of everyday cooking I like to use ground 
pork as ground pork and eggs is such a classic

combination in Thai cuisine but for something 
a little special I like to use crab meat so I'm

using crab meat and mushrooms today not just any 
mushrooms black fungus black fungus looks like

this has an interesting smell but really not 
a whole lot of flavor in there what I'm using

this for is texture it's super crunchy so this 
is the dry form it's widely available in Asian

grocery stores and you just soak it in some water 
it doesn't take long 10-15 minutes and it'll bloom

into this sort of flower like thing what I did is 
I just cut it two little strips okay like that and

it will add a little crunchy treasures underneath 
all the custard so I want to put that in first
a

the most important thing about this is that the 
water needs to be on low low heat as low as you

can maintain a gentle simmer if the water is 
boiling vigorously the heat is too high and

your eggs are going to have lots of bubbles in it 
and it's not going to have a nice smooth texture

and if you don't have a massive steamer like I do 
you can also use a big stockpot and then get one

of those steamer racks that fit inside a pot and 
then you know put a lid on it and then you have

yourself a steamer lid there you go so in order 
to prevent the heat from getting too high I'm

going to keep the lid ajar by sticking something 
chopsticks work or anything that will sort of keep

the lid somewhat open like this so that way any 
excess heat can also escape and you won't overcook

the eggs the timing for this is a bit tricky it 
depends on a lot of factors the size of your cups

is one the heat of the steam is another one and 
also the temperature of the custard going in your

eggs are cold the stock is cold it's going to 
take a bit longer if everything's at room temp

it's not going to take as long so in my experience 
that size takes anywhere from 8 to 15 minutes okay

so check often and early so we'll be right back 
these took a bit longer the important thing is

the testing of doneness there's a couple ways 
of doing it first of all when you open it the

eggs should be puffed up just slightly and then I 
like to do the jiggle test first and that is when

you jiggle it a bit it should jiggle like jello 
but it shouldn't sort of do this wavy thing it'll

be obviously liquid if it's not done another 
sure way to do it is to take a knife and just

stick it right in the center and if you push 
it apart a little bit there should be nothing

but clear broth that's in that crack if it's 
not done you see the cloudy custard the liquid

egg custard that'll come rushing through through 
that crack that you just made so you stick it in

and it's fine it's good to go so let these cool 
down a little bit so it's easier to handle and

to garnish I just like to put a little extra crab 
meat on top just to be a visual representation of

what's inside and especially when it's something 
expensive like crab you want to show that off if

you've got some fried garlic like the one I showed 
in my garlic pepper chicken episode that is good

stuff to drizzle on at the fried garlic with the 
garlic oil mmm I don't know why I didn't do that

for this video I just forgot greenery with some 
extra green onions oh so cute and there you go

what a great little appetizer I mean it's it's 
light so it works really well as an appetizer

or breakfast if you want to do this for breakfast 
just reheat it gently on like I do 40% microwave

because you don't want to overcook this that hot 
yes so put it on fit mmm look how soft and jiggly

this is I love it mmm I love this for breakfast 
but I also love just pouring this over rice if

you're familiar with Japanese food this is very 
similar to what they call Chawan mushi kids are

gonna love it who's not spicy I can go on and on 
about how wonderful this is and I can stand here

and keep eating because it's so so yummy it's 
perfect comfort food mmm and serve it with a

cute little spoon perfect if you want to make 
this the recipe is on hot hsn.com when you do

make it send me a photo Facebook Twitter 
or Instagram I love seeing your photos so

keep them coming and I guess I will see you 
next time for your next delicious Thai meal
